threats.title: Expedition
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #6:
Using speed to violate explicit or implicit assumptions about the application’s normal use to achieve unfair individual gain
threats.mitigation: Defences include providing enforcement of behavioral workflow and anti-automation

threats.title: Vulnerability scanning
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #14:
Systematic enumeration and examination in order to find weaknesses and points where a security vulnerability might exist
threats.mitigation: Defence includes providing anti-automation

threats.title: Denial of Service
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #15:
Usage may resemble legitimate application usage but leads to exhaustion of resources
threats.mitigation: Mitigation or prevention such as providing backoff, resource management and avoiding forced deadlock

threats.title: Footprinting
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #18:
Information gathering with the objective of learning as much as possible about the composition, configuration and security mechanisms of the application
threats.mitigation: Defences include shutting down unnecessary services/ports and excluding information that could identify and compromise security of the organisation

threats.title: Use encryption
threats.description: Unencrypted data sent over a public network may be intercepted and read by an attacker
threats.mitigation: Data should be encrypted either at the message or transport level

threats.title: Fingerprinting
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #4:
Specific requests are sent to the application eliciting information in order to profile the application
threats.mitigation: Defence includes restricting what information is provided, for example version numbers and package details

threats.title: Vulnerable transport protocol
threats.description: Older transport protocols are vulnerable and have known vulnerabilities
threats.mitigation: Use up to date cryptography and transport protocols

threats.title: Fingerprinting

See OWASP Automated Threat #4:
Specific requests are sent to the application eliciting information in order to profile the application
threats.mitigation: Defence includes restricting what information is provided, for example version numbers and package details

threats.title: Scraping
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #11:
Collecting accessible data and/or processed output from the application
threats.mitigation: Detect fake or compromised accounts, ensure information is accessible only with authentication and authorisation

threats.title: Skewing
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #16:
Automated repeated clicking or requesting or submitting content, affecting application based metrics such as counts, and measures of frequency and/or rate
threats.mitigation: Defences include control of interaction frequency or proper enforcement of a single unique action

threats.title: Spamming
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #17:
Storing malicious such as malware, Iframe distribution, photographs & videos, advertisements, referrer spam and tracking/surveillance code
threats.mitigation: Defences include detecting embedded malicious code, controling interaction frequency and enforcement of a single unique action

threats.title: Credential cracking
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #7:
Brute force, dictionary and guessing attacks used against authentication processes of the application to identify valid account credentials
threats.mitigation:
Defences include restriction of excessive authentication attempts, control of interaction frequency and enforcement of a single unique action
- Add rate limit login form
- Implement Strong Password policy

threats.title: Account creation
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #19:
Bulk account creation, and sometimes profile population, by using the application’s account signup processes
threats.mitigation: Defences include control of interaction frequency, enforcement of a single unique a action and enforcement of behavioral workflow

threats.title: Account aggregation
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #20:
Compilation of credentials and information from multiple application accounts into another system
threats.mitigation: Defences include control of interaction frequency and prevention of abuse of functionality

threats.title: Coupon cracking
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #2:
Mass enumeration (for example coupon numbers, voucher codes, discount tokens) providing some form of user benefit within the application
threats.mitigation: Defences include providing anti-automation, guarding against brute force, and preventing abuse of functionality

threats.title: Scalping
threats.description:
See OWASP Automated Threat #5:
Mass acquisition of goods or services using the application in a manner that a normal user would be unable to undertake manually
threats.mitigation: Defences against this automated threat include control of interaction frequency, enforcement of a single unique a action and enforcement of behavioral workflow

threats.title: Vulnerable encryption algorithms
threats.description: Out of date encryption algorithms are vulnerable and have known vulnerabilities
threats.mitigation: Use up to date cryptography for all signatures and encryption
